articles.headline: Bank Officials Cited in Churn of Foreclosures
articles.snippet: An extensive federal examination of banks’ foreclosure practices found that managers ignored widespread errors after the 2008 housing market collapse.
articles.abstract: An extensive federal examination of banks’ foreclosure practices found that managers ignored widespread errors after the 2008 housing market collapse.
articles.lead_paragraph: Managers at major banks ignored widespread errors in the foreclosure process, in some cases instructing employees to adopt make-believe titles and speed documents through the system despite internal objections, according to a wide-ranging review by federal investigators.
articles.byline: By NELSON D. SCHWARTZ and J. B. SILVER-GREENBERG

articles.headline: Solyndra Is Blamed as Clean-Energy Loan Program Stalls
articles.snippet: Some companies contend that federal loans for developing fuel-efficient cars have dried up because of a political firestorm that followed the bankruptcy last year of the solar panel company Solyndra.
articles.abstract: Some companies contend that federal loans for developing fuel-efficient cars have dried up because of a political firestorm that followed the bankruptcy last year of the solar panel company Solyndra.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than $16 billion in loans authorized five years ago by Congress to develop fuel-efficient vehicles has yet to be disbursed, with applicants for the money complaining that the Energy Department is crippling plans for greener cars and trucks at a time of rising gas prices.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: Obama’s Rating Falls as Poll Reflects Volatility
articles.snippet: Despite improving job growth and an extended Republican primary, President Obama’s approval rating dropped substantially in recent weeks, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.abstract: Despite improving job growth and an extended Republican primary, President Obama’s approval rating dropped substantially in recent weeks, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite improving job growth and an extended Republican primary fight dividing his would-be opponents, President Obama is heading into the general election season on treacherous political ground, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Marjorie Connelly

articles.headline: Trade Issues With China Flare Anew
articles.snippet: On Tuesday, the United States, the European Union and Japan filed a case against China over its restrictions on exports of rare earth metals.
articles.abstract: On Tuesday, the United States, the European Union and Japan filed a case against China over its restrictions on exports of rare earth metals.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A month after Vice President Xi Jinping’s visit to the United States and Europe, the brief trade policy détente between China and its two biggest export markets is about to end.

articles.headline: Use of Homeless as Internet Hot Spots Backfires on Marketer
articles.snippet: A marketing agency caused a stir when it hired homeless people to walk around carrying Wi-Fi devices, offering Internet access in exchange for donations.
articles.abstract: A marketing agency caused a stir when it hired homeless people to walk around carrying Wi-Fi devices, offering Internet access in exchange for donations.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Which product at this year’s South by Southwest technology conference received more attention than perhaps any other?

articles.headline: Church Puts Legal Pressure on Abuse Victims’ Group
articles.snippet: The Survivors Network of those Abused by Priests said broad subpoenas in two Missouri sex-abuse cases were a means of intimidation, an accusation the church disputed.
articles.abstract: The Survivors Network of those Abused by Priests said broad subpoenas in two Missouri sex-abuse cases were a means of intimidation, an accusation the church disputed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Turning the tables on an advocacy group that has long supported victims of pedophile priests, lawyers for the Roman Catholic Church and priests accused of sexual abuse in two Missouri cases have gone to court to compel the group to disclose more than two decades of e-mails that could include correspondence with victims, lawyers, whistle-blowers, witnesses, the police, prosecutors and journalists.

articles.headline: U.S. Officials Debate Speeding Afghan Pullout
articles.snippet: With a belief in the White House that the mission’s costs now outweigh benefits, some suggest accelerating the drawdown, but military commanders remain opposed.
articles.abstract: With a belief in the White House that the mission’s costs now outweigh benefits, some suggest accelerating the drawdown, but military commanders remain opposed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is discussing whether to reduce American forces in Afghanistan by at least an additional 20,000 troops by 2013, reflecting a growing belief within the White House that the mission there has now reached the point of diminishing returns.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
